html:
Power blackouts in Cuba aren't "if"â€”they're "when" and "how long"

Your family already knows the drill. Candles ready, phone charged, fridge closed tight. But a solar generator? That changes everything. Suddenly the fan keeps spinning, the phone stays charged, and abuela's nebulizer works when it needs to.

Two brands dominate this space: Jackery and Bluetti. Both make excellent portable power stations. But which one actually makes sense for Cubaâ€”where humidity eats electronics, voltage fluctuates, and shipping costs can rival the product price? Let's break it down.

Here's what most buying guides won't tell you: the "best" solar generator for camping in Colorado is not the best choice for surviving apagones in Havana. Different priorities entirely. You need something that handles humidity without corroding, charges fast when the grid flickers back on, and has enough capacity to actually matter during 8-12 hour blackouts.

Both Jackery and Bluetti use LiFePO4 (lithium iron phosphate) batteries in their newer modelsâ€”that's the good stuff. More charge cycles, better heat tolerance, longer lifespan. Critical for a climate that punishes lesser batteries. But the similarities end there. Wattage, charging speeds, port configurations, and build quality vary significantly across their lineups.

I've analyzed hundreds of reviews, compared specs, and factored in what actually matters for Cuban conditions. The winner might surprise you.

âš¡ The Quick Answer

For most Cuban families: the Bluetti AC180 wins on raw power output (1800W vs 1500W), faster charging, and slightly better value. But if portability matters more than peak wattage, the Jackery Explorer 1000 v2 is lighter and more compact. Both are excellentâ€”your choice depends on what you're powering.

See Bluetti AC180 on Amazon

The Power Champion: Bluetti AC180

Editor's Pick

Bluetti AC180 Portable Power Station

4.6â˜… (465 reviews) â€¢ $$$$$

1152Wh capacity with 1800W continuous output (2700W surge). That's enough to run a full-size refrigerator, multiple fans, and charge devices simultaneously. The 0-80% charge in 45 minutes is genuinely impressiveâ€”when the power comes back, you're ready fast.

  • âœ“ 2 AC outlets (handles 220V Cuban appliances with adapter)
  • âœ“ LiFePO4 battery rated for 3,500+ cycles
  • âœ“ Power Lifting mode pushes to 2700W for demanding loads
  • âœ“ App control via Bluetooth

VERDICT: The best balance of power, speed, and longevity for serious blackout protection.

Check Price on Amazon

Head-to-Head: The 1000Wh Class

This is where most families should focus. Enough capacity for essentials, portable enough to ship without breaking the bank.

Best for Portability

Jackery Explorer 1000 v2

4.7â˜… (475 reviews) â€¢ $$$$$

1070Wh â€¢ 1500W output â€¢ 1hr fast charge

Pros: Lighter weight, excellent build quality, 100W USB-C output, proven reliability

Cons: Lower wattage (1500W vs 1800W), fewer AC outlets

Check Price â†’
2025 Model

Bluetti Elite 100 V2 (2025)

4.5â˜… (New) â€¢ $$$$$

1024Wh â€¢ 1800W (3600W surge) â€¢ 35% smaller

Pros: 4 AC outlets, massive surge capacity, compact 2025 design, UPS backup mode

Cons: Brand new (limited real-world reviews), slightly less capacity

Check Price â†’
"The Bluetti's 1800W output means you can run the refrigerator AND the fan. The Jackery's 1500W means you're choosing between them."

Calculate What Your Family Actually Needs

Every household is different. Use this calculator to figure out the right capacity based on typical blackout duration and what needs to stay running.

For Extended Blackouts: The 2000Wh Class

When 8-hour blackouts become 24-hour blackouts, you need serious capacity. The Jackery Explorer 2000 v2 is built for exactly this scenario.

Jackery Explorer 2000 v2

4.7â˜… (475 reviews) â€¢ $$$$$

2042Wh of LiFePO4 capacity with 2200W output. This beast can run a small refrigerator for over 24 hours, power medical equipment through extended outages, or keep an entire household's essentials running. The 100W USB-C PD port handles modern devices efficiently.

VERDICT: Overkill for short blackouts, essential for the long ones. If you're in a province with worse grid reliability, this is the one.

Check Price on Amazon

Budget-Friendly Options (Still Worth Considering)

Not everyone needs 1000+ watts. For phone charging, LED lights, and small fans, these compact options deliver solid value.

Jackery Explorer 300

4.6â˜… (465 reviews) â€¢ $$$$$

293Wh capacity. Perfect for phones, tablets, LED lights, and small fans. Compact and lightweightâ€”easy to ship.

Best for: Basic essentials, backup charging

Check Price â†’

Bluetti AC50B

4.6â˜… (465 reviews) â€¢ $$$$$

448Wh with 700W output (1000W with Power Lifting). More versatile than the Jackery 300, charges 0-80% in 45 min.

Best for: Small appliances, faster charging needs

Check Price â†’

Quick Specs Comparison

Model Capacity Output Charge Time Best For
Bluetti AC180 1152Wh 1800W 45 min (0-80%) Refrigerators, high-demand
Jackery 1000 v2 1070Wh 1500W 1 hour Portability, reliability
Jackery 2000 v2 2042Wh 2200W ~2 hours Extended outages, provinces
Bluetti AC50B 448Wh 700W 45 min (0-80%) Budget, small appliances
Jackery 300 293Wh 300W ~2 hours Phones, lights, basics

Interactive Comparison

Estimate Shipping Costs

These units are heavy. Factor shipping into your total cost before deciding.

ðŸ‡¨ðŸ‡º Cuba-Specific Considerations

  • Voltage: Both brands output standard 110V AC. Cuban homes use 110V/220Vâ€”most modern appliances work fine, but verify before connecting anything.
  • Humidity: LiFePO4 batteries handle heat better than lithium-ion, but store the unit in a dry place when not in use.
  • Solar panels: Sold separately. Worth the investment if your family has roof accessâ€”free charging during the day.
  • Customs: Solar generators are generally allowed, but declare them properly. Lithium batteries under 100Wh have fewer restrictions.
  • Shipping weight: The Jackery 2000 v2 weighs ~43 lbs. Factor this into shipping costsâ€”it's not cheap.

The Bottom Line

For most families: The Bluetti AC180 offers the best combination of power, charging speed, and value. That 1800W output handles refrigerators and fans simultaneouslyâ€”something the Jackery 1000 v2 can't match.

For extended outages or rural areas: The Jackery Explorer 2000 v2 provides double the capacity for those 24+ hour blackouts that hit the provinces hardest.

On a budget: The Bluetti AC50B punches above its weight with Power Lifting mode and fast charging.

Get the Bluetti AC180 See Jackery 2000 v2
